thread.title_full: Esquire names new N.J. restaurant one of 15 best in U.S.

author: Vicki Hyman | NJ Advance Media for NJ.com
title: Esquire names new N.J. restaurant one of 15 best in U.S.
text:
Comments 
Morristown's Jockey Hollow Kitchen & Bar has been named to Esquire's highly-regarded Best New Restaurants list, the first time a Garden State restaurant has made the long-running list in at least a decade, if ever. 
It's more redemption for restauranteur Chris Cannon, who was edged out of his New York City restaurant partnership with celebrity chef Michael White (it included Marea, named to Esquire's list in 2009) a few years ago. 
Cannon, a New York native who married a Jersey girl and moved to Mountain Lakes to raise their children, decided to focus on this side of the Hudson, transforming the historic but decrepit Vail Mansion into an ambitious conglomeration of dining destinations: an oyster bar and '20-style cocktail lounge on the main level, fine dining up the massive stone staircase, and a beer hall in the basement that once housed the town jail. 
RELATED: Morristown's Jockey Hollow: New York City restaurateur changing Jersey dining 
And of course the recognition is a testament to opening chef Kevin Sippel, whose locally-sourced but Italian inspired menu includes seared Barnegat Bay scallops with an oyster beurre blanc, Sicilian-style roast chicken with grilled lemon and Sardinian fregola, scrambled hen egg with black truffle and Mangalitsa lardo, and sweetbread saltimbocca that moved the Esquire reviewer "close to honest tears." 
"Jersey is so misunderstood, so maligned," Cannon told Esquire. "Three quarters of the stuff from the Union Square greenmarket is coming from New Jersey. My staff, all the key guys, moved from the city out here." 
RELATED: 10 hottest places to eat in New Jersey in October 
Jockey Hollow was one of six restaurants on the list of 15 to get a feature in the magazine, though Esquire singled out Shaya, an Israeli restaurant in New Orleans, as the best new restaurant in America. 
Four New York City restaurants also made the cut: Little Park in Noho; the high-end sushi restaurant Shuko ; Santina , the newest hot spot from the buzzy Major Food Group ; and the fowl-focused Mountain Bird in Harlem.
